title: Sleep Efficiency Project
text:
CS graduate from UMT Lahore who loves to travel and is passionate about data analysis and machine learning. Actively exploring R and statistical modeling to deepen my data science expertise. Always learning, always curious.



Sleep Efficiency Predictor
Description:
A data-driven project analyzing how physiological and lifestyle factors affect sleep efficiency. It uses sleep patterns, wake/sleep habits, and behaviors (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, smoking, exercise) to model and visualize sleep quality.

 This project was developed as part of
Kane‚Äôs Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Sleep Predictor
text:
AUTHOR
Abdul Hannan   HOW DO LIFESTYLE HABITS IMPACT SLEEP EFFICIENCY?

title: Sleep Predictor
text:
üõå Sleep Efficiency & Lifestyle Habits
This dataset explores how lifestyle habits ‚Äî such as exercise, caffeine, alcohol, and smoking ‚Äî affect sleep efficiency. Originally published on Kaggle in 2021, the data combines detailed sleep tracking information with daily behavioral patterns from anonymous individuals.


üéØ Objective
The goal of this analysis is to understand how everyday behaviors influence the quality of sleep, as measured by sleep efficiency.



üî¨ Modeling Sleep Efficiency
We modeled sleep efficiency as a linear function of several lifestyle variables: - üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Exercise Frequency - ‚òï Caffeine Consumption - üç∑ Alcohol Intake - üö¨ Smoking Status



üìà Key Findings

Individuals who exercise more frequently tend to have higher sleep efficiency.
Higher caffeine or alcohol consumption is generally linked to poorer sleep quality.
For every unit increase in exercise frequency, sleep efficiency improves by ~3% (¬±0.5%).


üí° Insight: Regular physical activity appears to be the strongest predictor of better sleep in this dataset.

title: Sleep Efficiency Analysis by Lifestyle Factors
text:
Exploring the Relationship Between Sleep Habits and Quality







This scatter plot shows how sleep duration (hours) and sleep efficiency (%) are related, separated by gender. Most people sleep between 6 to 9 hours, and the best sleep efficiency usually happens with 7 to 8 hours of sleep. Both male and female participants show similar patterns, meaning their sleep quality follows the same trend.
 How different activity levels relate to sleep quality?







This box plot shows how often people exercise in a week and how it affects their sleep efficiency. People who exercise more days tend to have slightly better sleep quality. However, there is still a lot of variation, meaning not everyone who exercises more always sleeps better. Regular exercise seems to be linked with better sleep for many people.
 How smoking habits relate to sleep quality?






 This bar plot shows how much time people spend in each sleep stage based on their smoking status. Non-smokers tend to have better deep and REM sleep compared to smokers. Smoking seems to reduce the amount of deep and REM sleep, which are important for feeling rested. So, smoking may hurt sleep quality by affecting the balance of sleep stages.

Exploring relationships among health and habit variables






 This heatmap shows how different sleep and lifestyle factors are related to each other. Dark red means a strong positive connection, while dark blue means a strong negative one. For example, more awakenings are linked with lower sleep efficiency, while longer sleep is linked with better sleep efficiency. It helps us quickly see which habits might improve or harm sleep quality.

title: Predicting Sleep Efficiency: Model Comparison and Explanation

  ## üìä Statistical Model
We use a linear regression model to estimate how age and smoking status affect sleep efficiency:
\[
\hat{Y} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Age} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{SmokingStatus}_{\text{Yes}} + \epsilon
\]
This model assumes:

Y = sleep efficiency

Age = age of the participant

SmokingStatusYes = 1 if smoker, 0 if non-smoker

Œ≤‚ÇÄ = intercept (baseline sleep efficiency)

Œ≤‚ÇÅ, Œ≤‚ÇÇ = effect of each predictor

Œµ = random error not explained by predictors




Estimates and 95% Confidence Intervals for Parameters

title: Predicting Sleep Efficiency
text:
We use a linear regression model to estimate which lifestyle or demographic variables best predict sleep efficiency:
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \cdots + \beta_n X_n + \epsilon
\]
Where:

Y = sleep efficiency

X‚ÇÅ, X‚ÇÇ, ‚Ä¶, X‚Çô = predictors (e.g., age, smoking status, caffeine consumption)

Œµ = unexplained error

üìä Statistical Model
We use a linear regression model to estimate how age and smoking status affect sleep efficiency:
\[
\hat{Y} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Age} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{SmokingStatus}_{\text{Yes}} + \epsilon

This model assumes:

  ## üìù Summary of Analysis

We compared three linear models with different predictors to explain sleep efficiency.
The best-performing model included age and smoking status as predictors.
Smoking was associated with lower sleep efficiency, even after adjusting for age.
Age also had a small negative effect on sleep quality.
These results suggest that both lifestyle factors (like smoking) and demographics (like age) influence sleep health.

title: Sleep Efficiency Project
text:
This project explores how lifestyle and body-related factors affect sleep efficiency.
The dataset includes details like sleep patterns, bedtime/wake-up times, and personal habits such as caffeine, alcohol, smoking, and exercise.
I used AI tools for cleaning messy data, making visual plots, and applying models to find useful patterns.
The data was collected from Kaggle and is part of a capstone project.
üîó Sleep Efficiency Dataset on Kaggle
